project_metadata.paper_title: Modelling diffusion of innovation curves using radiocarbon data
project_metadata.journal: Journal of Archaeological Science, Vol. 165, Article 105962
project_metadata.research_context: Novel Bayesian framework for inferring diffusion curves using radiocarbon data. Develops hierarchical and non-parametric models to estimate changing proportions of innovations over time while accounting for chronological uncertainty, inter-site variation, and small sample sizes. Applied to three case studies: diffusion of rice farming in Japan, wheat/barley farming in Britain, and burial practice changes in later prehistoric Britain.

evidence.evidence_text: Japanese radiocarbon dataset: 551 dates from 215 sites, including rice (n=203) and wild nuts (n=348)
evidence.verbatim_quote: We examined a total of 1479 14C dates on seed remains from Japan (n = 551, from 215 sites, Fig. 1a)

source_verification.source: Kudo et al. 2023; Crema et al. 2022

evidence.evidence_text: British radiocarbon dataset: 928 dates from 314 sites, including wheat (n=261), barley (n=130), and hazelnut (n=537)
British burial dataset: 2536 dates (cremation n=1417, inhumation n=1119)
evidence.verbatim_quote: We examined the source material to distinguish dates associated with cremation (n = 1417) and inhumation (n = 1119)

evidence.evidence_text: Hierarchical model successfully recovered simulated diffusion curve parameters within 95% posterior range
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our hierarchical approach was able to accurately recover the shape of the diffusion curve in both simulated datasets, with the 'true' curve within the 95% posterior fitted range

evidence.evidence_text: ICAR model successfully recovered simulated time-sequence patterns
evidence.verbatim_quote: The non-parametric ICAR approach successfully recovered the 'true' time-sequence of p used to generate the simulated dataset 2

evidence.evidence_text: Japanese case study: posterior predictive check shows poor fit between sigmoid model and observed data
evidence.verbatim_quote: Results of the posterior predictive checks of the Japanese and British datasets (Figs. 3 and 4) have, instead, revealed a poor fit between the model and the empirically observed proportion SPDs, suggesting in both cases that the diffusion processes cannot be described by a sigmoid curve

evidence.evidence_text: Japanese diffusion parameters: r=0.1023, m=844 BCE, μ=0.703, φ=0.75
British diffusion parameters: r=0.0136, m=4053 BCE, μ=0.182, φ=0.31
Two major cremation cycles identified: Late Neolithic peak ~2900 BCE, Early-Middle Bronze Age ~1900-1200 BCE
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our empirical case study revealed the existence of two major cycles of diffusion and abandonment of cremation; one peaking in the Late Neolithic at around 2900 BCE and the other in the Early to Middle Bronze Age around 1900-1200 BCE

evidence.evidence_text: Rapid cremation transition 2050-1950 BCE: ~10% to ~80% prevalence
evidence.verbatim_quote: A key finding for this cycle is the speed at which a transition from ~10% to ~80% prevalence occurs, the century 2050–1950 BCE seeing a particularly rapid shift in practices

claims.claim_text: The new Bayesian framework can infer diffusion of innovation curves from radiocarbon data while accounting for chronological uncertainty, inter-site variation, and small sample sizes
claims.verbatim_quote: This paper introduces a novel Bayesian framework for inferring the shape of diffusion curves using radiocarbon data associated with the presence/absence of a particular innovation

claims.claim_text: Both hierarchical and ICAR models can accurately recover diffusion curve parameters from simulated data
claims.verbatim_quote: Our hierarchical approach was able to accurately recover the shape of the diffusion curve in both simulated datasets... The non-parametric ICAR approach successfully recovered the 'true' time-sequence

claims.claim_text: The hierarchical model accounts for inter-site variation in sampling probability while simultaneously modelling the general rate of diffusion
claims.verbatim_quote: The hierarchical model described above effectively accounts for any inter-site variation in the probability of dating a domesticate rather than a non-domesticate, while simultaneously modelling the general rate of diffusion of agriculture

claims.claim_text: The ICAR model provides a non-parametric solution for cases where diffusion does not follow s-shaped curves
claims.verbatim_quote: The flexibility of the non-parametric model provides a clear advantage under these conditions and, more generally, in cases where we do not expect an s-shaped diffusion curve to begin with

claims.claim_text: Rice agriculture diffusion in Japan shows a double s-shape pattern with intervals of slowdown between metapopulations
claims.verbatim_quote: In the case of Japan, the dispersal of rice agriculture is known to have been characterised by episodes of significant regional accelerations and slowdowns (Crema et al., 2022), which might explain why the observed diffusion curve (Fig. 3) can be described as a double s-shape

claims.claim_text: British farming diffusion shows temporary abandonment of crops in favour of pastoralism and wild resources before reintroduction in Beaker period
claims.verbatim_quote: Previous studies (Bevan et al., 2017; Stevens et al., 2022; Stevens and Fuller, 2012, 2015) have already revealed a shift in subsistence towards total reliance on pastoralism and wild food resources, accompanied in many regions of mainland Britain by the abandonment of crops and cultivation

claims.claim_text: British burial practices show two major cycles of cremation adoption/abandonment, with decline pre-dating Beaker phenomenon by several centuries
claims.verbatim_quote: However, the decline in cremation is marked from 2800 BCE onwards and thus pre-dates Beaker inhumation practices in Britain by several centuries, suggesting that this decline may reflect endogenous factors rather than external influences

claims.claim_text: Posterior predictive checks allow identification of deviations from expected diffusion patterns, providing more robust assessment than traditional SPD approaches
claims.verbatim_quote: Our solution overcomes several problems that affect current approaches based on SPDs, including sampling error, calibration-based artefacts, and overdispersion arising from inter-site variation

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Direct radiocarbon dates on seeds provide more reliable chronological control than dates on associated materials, despite reducing sample sizes
trigger_text: Statistical analyses of diffusion rates of farming in Japan and Britain (and most likely in other regions of the world) have a number of shared challenges. For example, the direct dating of seeds can overcome some of the problems associated with chronological and contextual uncertainty but also drastically reduces sample sizes
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors justify using direct dates despite smaller sample sizes, implying this trade-off is worthwhile for improved accuracy

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Model misfit (poor posterior predictive checks) is informative rather than simply indicating failure, as it reveals deviations from expected patterns
trigger_text: While this might be interpreted as a negative result, we highlight that our posterior predictive check provided means to identify whether and, more importantly, how the empirical data deviates from the expectation
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Authors reframe poor model fit as a useful diagnostic outcome rather than a limitation

research_designs.design_text: Methods development and validation study: develop Bayesian hierarchical and non-parametric models, validate on simulated data, apply to three archaeological case studies
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We test the robustness of our approach via simulated datasets and two sets of case studies

research_designs.design_text: Simulation study: generate synthetic datasets with known parameters to validate model recovery
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We first examined the robustness of the two statistical approaches we developed by examining whether they can accurately recover parameter values when dealing with sample sizes comparable to those observed in the case studies

research_designs.design_text: Case study application: apply developed methods to empirical archaeological radiocarbon datasets
research_designs.verbatim_quote: then applied to investigate three case studies

methods.method_text: Hierarchical Bayesian model for sigmoid diffusion curves with site-level random effects
methods.verbatim_quote: a hierarchical model that enables the fitting of an s-shaped diffusion curve whilst accounting for inter-site variations in the probability of sampling the innovation itself

methods.method_text: Intrinsic Gaussian Conditional Autoregressive (ICAR) model for non-parametric diffusion estimation
methods.verbatim_quote: a non-parametric model that can estimate the changing proportion of the innovation across user-defined time-blocks

methods.method_text: Simulation-based validation with known generating parameters
methods.verbatim_quote: We simulated three datasets with sample sizes and time-windows equivalent to each observed dataset

methods.method_text: Posterior predictive checks for model adequacy assessment
methods.verbatim_quote: We also carried out posterior predictive checks for the two empirical case studies by visually comparing observed SPDs of the proportion of domesticated crops to an envelope of predictions

protocols.protocol_text: MCMC fitting for hierarchical model: 4 chains, 1 million iterations, 50% burn-in, thinning=50
protocols.verbatim_quote: We fitted all four models with the same MCMC settings, using four chains, each with 1 million iterations (half discarded as burn-in) and with thinning set to 50

protocols.protocol_text: Prior specification: r~Exponential(100), μ~Beta(2,2), φ~Gamma(5,0.1), m~Normal truncated to analysis window
protocols.verbatim_quote: r ∼ Exponential(100), μ ∼ Beta(2, 2), φ ∼ Gamma(5, 0.1)

protocols.protocol_text: ICAR model fitting: 36 time-blocks of 100 years, 4 chains, 100,000 iterations, 20% burn-in, thinning=4
protocols.verbatim_quote: The ICAR model for case study 2 and the simulation dataset 2 was fitted using 36 time-blocks of 100 years... we used four chains, each with 100,000 iterations (20,000 of which were discarded for burn-in), with parameters collected every four steps

protocols.protocol_text: Data simulation: uniform calendar dates within time window, back-calibration, 20-year error, random site clustering
protocols.verbatim_quote: Calendar dates were uniformly generated within the time window of analyses, back-calibrated in 14C age, and associated with an arbitrary error of 20 years

protocols.protocol_text: Posterior predictive check: compare observed proportion SPD to simulation envelope from 1000 posterior samples
protocols.verbatim_quote: by visually comparing observed SPDs of the proportion of domesticated crops to an envelope of predictions generated using 1000 randomly selected parameters from the joint posterior distributions

protocols.protocol_text: Convergence diagnostics: Gelman-Rubin statistic for parameters, agreement indices for calendar dates
protocols.verbatim_quote: We evaluated the mixing of our model using the Gelman-Rubin statistic (Gelman and Rubin, 1992), except for the posterior of the individual dates (θ), which were examined using agreement indices
We used the IntCal20 curve for all models (Reimer et al., 2020)

data_availability.statement_text: All data and R scripts are available on https://github.com/ercrema/diffusionCurve and permanently archived on https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10782942.

code_availability.statement_text: All data and R scripts are available on https://github.com/ercrema/diffusionCurve and permanently archived on https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10782942.

machine_actionability.rationale: GitHub repository with Zenodo DOI archival. R code with reproducible workflow. Uses NIMBLE and nimbleCarbon packages. Dependencies managed through R package ecosystem.

materials_availability.description: Computational methods paper - no physical materials

statements: This work was supported by the European Research Council Starting Grant (ENCOUNTER; no. 801953; ERC & CJS; PI: ERC) a Philip Leverhulme Prize (#PLP-2019–304; PI: ERC), NERC radiocarbon grant (NF/2017/2/12; AB; PI: Mike Parker Pearson), and LAHP AHRC studentship (AB).

ethics.statement_text: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

reproducibility_review.notes: Ben Marwick (JAS Reproducibility Specialist) reviewed the computational code and provided suggestions to improve its reproducibility.

pass0_metadata.notes: Paper is open access under CC BY licence. Authors listed with initials only on title page; full names inferred from established research community knowledge. Methods paper developing novel Bayesian framework.

pass1_2_claims_evidence.notes: Methods paper with strong quantitative evidence base. Core claims are methodological (model development and validation) and empirical (case study findings). Evidence includes simulation results, parameter estimates, and posterior predictive diagnostics.

pass3_5_rdmap.notes: Clear three-tier hierarchy: methods development design validated through simulation then applied to case studies. Detailed MCMC protocols fully specified.

pass6_infrastructure.notes: Excellent reproducibility infrastructure. Code and data archived on Zenodo with DOI. CRediT author contributions statement present. Four funding sources documented. Reproducibility review by Ben Marwick noted in acknowledgements. CC BY licence for open access.
